title: Building A JavaServer Faces Application
summary: In this tutorial, we will create a simple JavaServer Faces application with a single view and a few managed beans. This application will contain a form that accepts a user input, and once submitted, the application will display the data entered by the user. The data can be stored in JavaBeans-like fields and can be manipulated in the same way as regular editors and validators. We will also define a simple bean-scoped bean-managed bean-entry method and define a view.

This makes JSF a framework that uses XML markup instead of code for building and rendering user interfaces.
A JavaServer Faces application basically is a collection of a views, managed by a controller, stored in an archive file and deployed on a servlet container. Such applications are known as \u201Cheavyweight\u201D because there are many different pieces involved to build it.
As we know, JavaServer Faces technology comes with several built-in tag libraries and default libraries such as standard action message, navigation rule, focus handler, and so on. Each library offers handlers or actions that enable you to use different components in your application. These components can be combined in any way you want to meet your specific requirements.
In this article we will go over what you need to get started creating a new JavaServer Faces application project in IntelliJ IDEA`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

To do that, choose File | New | Project from the menu. Then, select the Java category and on the next screen choose the JavaServer Faces category. In the ensuing dialog box, select the Basic (JSF 2.x) option and click Next. On the next screen, specify a suitable Java package, project name, and click Finish to create the project."),mdx("p",null,"For the purpose of this tutorial, we will create a simple JavaServer Faces application with a single view and a few managed beans. This application will contain a form that accepts a user input, and once submitted, the application will display the data entered by the user. ## Set up Java and Gradle"),mdx("p",null,"In order to use JavaServer Faces in IntelliJ IDEA, we need to select the Java 9 runtime as the project's default JDK. This can be done in the Project Structure dialog box by adding a new JDK, selecting the desired version from the drop-down list, and clicking OK."),mdx("p",null,"We also need to configure the build tool and source control settings. To do that, open the Settings/Preferences dialog box, select Build, Execution, Deployment | Compilers, and click Java Compiler. From the Java Compiler dialog box, select the desired version, the source folder, and the Target folder. Then, select the Standard JVM Code Path."),mdx("p",null,"Next, select the Gradle version and choose the location of the Gradle wrapper. Finally, enable the Use Source and Target folders option and disable the Show only selected items option. ## Configuring JVM Options"),mdx("p",null,"We will configure JVM options to enable the following options: -Xms512m -Xmx2048m -XX:PermSize=256m -XX:MaxPermSize=512m -Dsun.java2d.noddraw=false -Dorg.apache.logging.Log=org.apache.logging.log4j.Logger -Dlog4j.logger.org.apache.logging.log4j.LogManager=DEBUG,console -Dlog4j.logger.org.apache.logging.log4j.Logger=WARN,console -Dlog4j.logger.org.eclipse.jdt.core.compiler=WARN,console -Dlog4j.logger.com.intellij.util.logging.InternalLoggerFactory=DEBUG,console -Dorg.eclipse.jdt.core.compiler.source=1.9 -Dorg.eclipse.jdt.core.compiler.target=1.9 -Dorg.eclipse.jdt.core.compiler.misc=true ## Create Facelets Folder and Viewing Template"),mdx("p",null,"As JavaServer Faces applications are built with Facelet files, we need to create a new folder named \u201Cweb\u201D in the root of our project and place the Facelet files there. For creating a new folder in the root of a project, we can use the \u201CFile | New | Folder\u201D menu."),mdx("p",null,"We also need to create a template view for our application. In the \u201Cweb\u201D folder, create another folder named \u201Cfaces\u201D and place the view there. To create a view for our application, select the \u201Cfaces\u201D folder and choose \u201CFile | New | Other\u201D from the menu. On the dialog box that opens, select JavaServer Faces view from the \u201CTemplates\u201D drop-down list and click Next. In the \u201CNew JavaServer Faces View\u201D dialog box, type the name of the view and the path where the view is saved. Confirm that the \u201CView Root\u201D field is set to \u201C/\u201D, the \u201CProject\u201D field is set to the current project, and the \u201CView Engine\u201D field is set to \u201CNo Engine\u201D. Click Finish to create the template view. ## Define Application Beans and \xA0View-scoped Beans"),mdx("p",null,"For the purpose of this tutorial, we will define a simple managed bean with a single properties entry and a method. We will also define a view-scoped bean."),mdx("p",null,"Managed beans are Java classes that are used to handle the data that is passed between the application and the browser. The data can be stored in a JavaBeans-like field and it can be manipulated in the same way as regular JavaBeans are manipulated, using property editors and validators."),mdx("p",null,"To define managed beans, open the view that we created in the previous step and open the \u201CContext\u201D tab. Here, we can define managed beans, set the application's faces context, get the application's faces context, and change the application's faces context. ## Create Activities to Show Conditions and Commit Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,"Now that we have set up the basic Facelet template, it is time to add logic. We can do this by creating activities that will show conditions and commit conclusion. We will define an activity to show \u201CNew Search\u201D when the user clicks the \u201CNew Search\u201D button. Another activity will show \u201CCancel\u201D when the user clicks \u201CCancel\u201D."),mdx("p",null,"An activity is a stateless, non-UI-driven, business process that executes outside the context of an HTTP request and is designed to orchestrate business process logic and/or utilize other services."),mdx("p",null,"In order to do this, open the view that we created earlier, choose the \u201CControls\u201D tab, and choose \u201CInsert View\u201D. Select the \u201CActivities\u201D tab and select \u201CNew JavaServer Faces Activity\u201D. In the \u201CNew JavaServer Faces Activity\u201D dialog box, enter the name of the activity and select the method to trigger the activity. Click Finish to create the activity. ## Conclusion"),mdx("p",null,"In this article, we went through what you need to get started creating a new JavaServer Faces application project in IntelliJ IDEA. We also discussed how to create Facelets, define managed beans, create activities, and concluded with a discussion about activities."))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

Everything is new, nothing makes sense and you can\u2019t even tell if you are on the right track or not. It feels like one confusing labyrinth with a lot of locked doors \u2013 every time you find an unlocked door, it just leads to another locked door! How do we get out of this frustrating loop? Coding shortcuts!
A lot of coders will tell you that in order to be a successful coder, you need to know everything about coding and all its ins and outs. However, there is a reason why even experienced programmers take note of coding shortcuts. This article lists programming languages used for web scraping and extracting data. Web scraping is the process of crawling websites to retrieve specific data in a machine-readable format. It is an area of data mining that covers computer programs that automatically read and extract information from websites or documents. These programs are called scrapers or crawlers. Scraping is a task you might need to complete as parter of your job as a digital marketer, software engineer, statistical analyst, or researcher.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;

Concurrently, businesses demand cost-effective solutions to meet these demands. This creates a need for high-performance, cross-platform apps that can be easily deployed on various devices. JavaFX can be your best bet for developing such apps.
With JavaFX, you can build rich client applications that are high performing, responsive, and have a natural user interface (NUI). If you\u2019re looking to break into this field or advance your career as an engineer, you must stand out from the crowd to land your dream job. Software engineers are in high demand across many industries, but some companies stand out as leaders in this field. These top software engineering companies help drive innovation and create new products and technologies that others can build upon.
If you want to work as a software engineer or break into the field with ease, consider exploring companies that hire software engineers. You might find a position with one of these top-rated companies or use your resume to apply directly at one of these firms. In addition to researching different companies, it\u2019s also important to research their specific software engineering roles and requirements so you can tailor your resume accordingly. This can be a tricky subject to get started on and continue with, but we\u2019re here to make it easy for you. Coding for beginners isn\u2019t as difficult as you might believe, it just requires some study time and practice. It won\u2019t come easily at first, but with time and the right amount of dedication, anyone can learn the fundamentals of coding whether they have prior knowledge or not.
Coding is becoming one of the most important skills in today\u2019s job market. Even if you don\u2019t want to become a software engineer or the like, understanding basic coding principles can give you an edge in almost any other field. Do you know which of these programming languages is right for your project? If so, read on to learn more!
In this blog post, we\u2019ll go over everything you need to know about TypeScript vs. JavaScript. Both of these programming languages are popular in the software development industry. However, they have some subtle yet important differences that set them apart from one another.
But first, before we dive into the details of each programming language, let\u2019s understand what they both have in common.
Both JavaScript and TypeScript are dynamic, object-oriented programming languages designed for creating websites and other interactive applications. They both support curly bracket syntax with optional semicolons, as well > operators for type checking, and if-else conditional statements. Both support variables, data types (string, boolean, number), and function calls with optional arguments and return values.`))}MDXContent.isMDXComponent=!0;
